Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was
What is your overall assessment of this course
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning
I received clear feedback that improved my learning
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain
Comments_List: I learned the fundamentals of calculus and data analysis.

Refresher course on math and calculus quintessentials; learned about the basics of how to use STATA to deal with variables and conduct simple statistical analyses; How to use and understand statistics in simplified and practical way

I gained deeper insight to the application of statistics. I also believe I developed a strong understanding of the calculus behind the statistics that I learned. 

I believe that the programming was taught in an easy to understand manner.

As someone who had never taken calculus before, I think Lloyd is an incredible professor.  I don't think anyone could have helped us learn like he did.  I wish we had more time with Stata.  The calculus helped in econ, but I think learning calculus in tandem with applying it in the econ class was over ambitious.
Statistical analysis and math.
I learned basic multivariate calculus, the basics of statistical regression (including multivariate regression), and how to use Stata.
Calculus, MV calculus, Stata, why statistics helps in terms of policy
Quantitative problem-solving skills

Much more than I expected when the course started. I was surprised by the calculus component and the statistical math but impressed by the professor's ability to teach everything in such a comprehensible manner.
This course provided strong basic foundations in calculus and statistical analysis using STATA.

The course focused on  derivatives, some probability, regressions, and how to use Stata. What I enjoyed most was learning about the subjective nature of statistical analysis and how biases impact quantitative work.

This class was great! A wonderful refresher of calc (with concepts explained in a way that actually made them make sense for the first time). I also feel like I got a decent beginners intro to STATA, which I plan to continue building on. The greatest strength was Lloyd - a fantastic teacher who was so committed to the students. We worked hard to learn because he worked hard to teach!
Applied data analysis

This course was excellent at drawing a clear line between the discipline of calculus and the art of statistical modeling, particularly with its focus on the application of both skill sets to relevant, current issues in social science.  The capstone project was an outstanding and engaging final assessment of my ability to apply the tools and intuitions I'd developed over the course of the semester.
I refreshed my knowledge of statistics and calculus and learned a lot about stata.
Calculus, stata.

Strengths: The course is really well organized and Lloyd is an extremely thoughtful and intentional professor. 
Weaknesses: The course can be somewhat unrelated to Global Affairs at times. The final project brings it back in focus, but it does seem to drift away from the study of Global Affairs during the bulk of the semester.

Strengths: Lloyd is a wonderful instructor. He makes sure to go over each step carefully and methodically. The level of preparation Lloyd shows in this class is simply impressive and many aspects of the class serve as a testament to his desire to see everyone really understand the material and succeed (regardless of their comfort level with quantitative analysis). 

Weaknesses: I understand that everyone comes into Jackson with differing levels of math/calculus proficiency, but I did feel that the first half of the class moved a little bit too slowly/many of the calculus concepts were not that necessary to begin analyzing basic level statistics. Alas, if you are mindful of the fact that this is more of a breadth course rather than a depth course, its fine.
I felt like some of the programming parts of the course were difficult to understand and engage with. I would have appreciated if we could code alongside Lloyd to better understand the process.

We've talked about this a lot amongst ourselves as students.   It seems to us that Lloyd loves teaching this material - so much so that he has designed a course that he wants to teach (not necessarily the course that would be of greatest use to us).  He consistently told us that we were going deep into the material because understanding the background of what Stata is doing is important.  But to be honest, virtually none of us in the program are going to be taking derivatives any time in our careers.  Spending two thirds of the class on calculus and only one third on research design and Stata is not a good combination for what we need professionally.  He says he was saving us time by not making us take a math camp over the summer, but I would have much rather been told I needed to learn calculus over the summer so that we could have spent the whole semester working in Stata and finding relationships in the data.  I had no idea calculus was going to be part of this class or the econ class, and I would have had a very different semester had I known how crucial it was to come into this program with a background in calculus. One other thing - Lloyd consistently went 10-15 minutes over at the end of class every day.  One student said he told them it's because in previous semesters the class was 1h30min, not 1h15min, and he has to cover the same amount of material.  When we only have short breaks between our classes, this doesn't work.  The material needs to be shortened.  Lloyd is an amazing teacher and a very compassionate human being, and I wouldn't trade him for a different instructor, but the course could benefit from a little restructuring.

Great instructor who really cares. It did not make me love stats, as some said it would. I think part of the reason that is so is that I did not think the course used data sets relevant to broader societal variables (beyond age and income). More interesting data sets would be good for this class. Also at the beginning, problem sets were not only long, but cumbersome. Half of the length would have been appropriate. Love Lloyd though - hes smart, energetic, and caring.
The course was well structured and classes were easy to follow. A little less time spent on the math part and more time on Stata could have been a better balance.

The strength of this course is that it takes students with little background in statistics and mathematics and gives us an understanding of descriptive statistics and multivariate calculus.  It also gives us the skills in Stata to be able to answer questions relating to datasets.
I wish more time will be allocated to Stata teaching and reduce the algebra teaching in the first two weeks of the semester.

Strengths: Lloyd is a great teacher and his class notes and teaching in class plus officer hours was incredibly helpful
Weaknesses: Lots of homework! But I guess it helped
Once we started working in STATA the course was less engaging, although I'm not sure how this can be improved as it seems to be inevitable given the nature of working in a programming language.

Problem sets were good practice to gain skills taught in class. Course materials were well organized and could easily be found on canvas. It's really difficult, but more engaging ways should be found to teach stata in class.

The course provided a strong basis in calculus but kind of glossed over probability. It seems like a more balanced approach could be taken. I for one would have been willing to show up for math camp in the early summer. It may have been a bit painful but it also would have been a chance for the class to bond.

Strengths: Everything, especially Lloyd's teaching.

Weaknesses: Honestly, none.
A math camp would have helped bring students on an equal footing with one another.

Strengths: painstaking breakdown of source material from the instructor--I haven't touched hard math skills in approximately 12 years, and Professor Grieger structured his classes, notes, and problem sets in such a way as to provide the density / repetitions I needed to regain proficiency in these skills, without making it fatal if I struggled in a particular area for some time.

Weaknesses: We went into great depth with calculus skills, but the programming skills required for the statistical modules felt comparatively rushed. 

Recommendation: Devise a way for students to participate in the statistical classes with their computers so that they are programming in real time; some problem sets were difficult because they were not directly linked to the same skills we'd learned in class (different data sets, different methods of coding).
This was taught very well- I thought we covered the material quickly but fairly thoroughly and I appreciated the emphasis on problem sets, as practice makes perfect.

Very thorough, and well taught, section on calculus. Less engaging, and more difficult to follow section on STATA. Did not find this later section very useful or engaging. Not sure how much use a mandatory STATA course is.

Absolutely, mostly because Lloyd is a great instructor. This could be a great introduction to quantitative analysis for those planning a career in non-research-based international development field.

This course is a requirement for Jackson MA students, so I am not sure whether recommend is the right word. The course does its job very well.
If there was an option to choose between this class and a research design/Stata class, I would choose the latter.
Yes - the teacher is pedagogically very strong and the course well structured.

I would recommend this course to another student. Prof Grieger is an excellent teacher and has put significant thought into how to teach this course.  It is well taught and you will learn the basic skills necessary to analyse human survey data sets. The class goes at a pace that allows everyone to learn the material. This course is quite different from the biological statistics courses I have taken in the past - this is not the course to take if biology is your area of interest.
Yes
Yes, great intro to statistics, taught in a practical and usable way.
Yes because it helps you gain greater facility with analyzing and working with data.
Probably not only considering what a specialized course it is within the program, with the math component covering both this and econ. But if someone needed that I certainly would.

This is a required course. If a student has to take a statistics course, Lloyd is an excellent professor to take statistics with! As mentioned elsewhere, my preference would be for more focus on research design and applying statistics to explore research questions. That said, I learned a lot from this course and thought it was well designed and executed to meet the course objectives.
Yes I would recommend the course for anyone looking for a basic analytic methods course.
Yes! A great class to brush up and learn from scratch!
Yes

100% and then some.  The cross-disciplinary design of this class (not just hard math, but math tailored to solving relevant problems in social policy) is precisely what I expected to be doing as a graduate student.
I would to students that haven't taken math in a while, as Lloyd was excellent.
